body: Jenkins failures are not related, there are JIRAs tracking these issues already.
LGTM. Merged to trunk and cherry-picked to 0.10.2.

@rajinisivaram, since we close the metrics on KafkaServer shutdown, the main problem remaining (assuming that brokers are always shutdown) is that multiple brokers share the same metric if the metric doesn't have a broker id tag.

@dguy @mjsax @enothereska As for fixing KAFKA-5006 itself, as I mentioned in the JIRA it seems more reasonable to catch the exception from RecordCollector.send() and re-throw at the coarsen-grained task-level with a more meaningful exception, e.g. "cannot complete the put operation since the state store's changelog may have been corrupted due to a previous error sending to it" etc.

More generally (out of the scope of this JIRA but let's tackle it in a more general story), we should consider what exceptions should we really re-throw v.s. handle it internally. For example, the callback's possible returned exceptions are listed in the javadocs:

```
he exception thrown during processing of this record. Null if no error occurred.
     *                  Possible thrown exceptions include:
     *
     *                  Non-Retriable exceptions (fatal, the message will never be sent):
     *
     *                  InvalidTopicException
     *                  OffsetMetadataTooLargeException
     *                  RecordBatchTooLargeException
     *                  RecordTooLargeException
     *                  UnknownServerException
     *
     *                  Retriable exceptions (transient, may be covered by increasing #.retries):
     *
     *                  CorruptRecordException
     *                  OffsetMetadataTooLargeException
     *                  NotEnoughReplicasAfterAppendException
     *                  NotEnoughReplicasException
     *                  OffsetOutOfRangeException
     *                  TimeoutException
     *                  UnknownTopicOrPartitionException
```

I am not actually sure if all the above are possible, we could go over that in producer client internals; but for streams layer, some of the exceptions should never be expected (.e.g. `OffsetMetadataTooLargeException`) and if happens it would likely be a bug, while some others are possible to happen (e.g. `OffsetOutOfRangeException` if user configure the changelog mistakenly that log retention was too small). For different cases we could log a different error message and handle them differently.

Thanks for the patch. I think, we should try to align this with other CLI tools. For example. `ConsoleConsumer.scala` uses `consumer-property` for specify configs as key-value-pairs on command line, and `consumer.config` to specify a consumer config file.

I think, we also need a KIP for this JIRA. \cc @gwenshap @ewencp @guozhangwang

@jeqo I think there is still some confusing terminology in the current patch. I submitted a PR to fix this along with a few simplifications: https://github.com/jeqo/kafka/pull/1. If it looks good, can you merge it here?

@ewencp @mjsax Proposed KIP 157 for this. Please let me know how to include this KIP 157 under main KIP for **config options for kafka tools**. As KIP 156 is also to add an option to reset tool. As if we include all KIP's related to tools under one main KIP, it will be easy to refer in future and also it will help further developers to use the similar naming convention for options in kafka tools.

@guozhangwang Note that we do print the fetch offsets in `createFetchRequests`, but the level is TRACE. We could also just bump that up to DEBUG. I'm not sure how useful the fetch size is since it comes straight from configuration.
What was the bug that these changes fixed? Or was the `time.milliseconds` parameter making it flaky?

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/3963/
Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).
@hachikuji sounds good. I agree fetch size is less important. I will bump up the `createFetchRequests` log to DEBUG.

@apurvam It can happen that one of the log segments is created at the same timestamp as the call to `doClean`. If that happens, that segment won't be eligible for deletion. Since the intent of the test case is to make _all_ segments eligible for deletion, I changed the test to use `Long.MaxValue`. In addition to guaranteeing all segments are eligible for deletion, it better conveys the intent of the test.

This is a WIP built on top of https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2458, so you're seeing a larger diff than is ideal. The primary addition here is the `TimestampConverter` transformation in the last commit (9eafd31). I'm filing this now for review of the new bits, and can re-file or rebase as needed.
/cc @kkonstantine @hachikuji @gwenshap
/cc @gwenshap Not sure how I omitted you thus far, pretty sure you want to see some of these transformations included :)
@ewencp Trying to reclaim the LOC lead, eh?

```
ERROR Producer has become invalid, which typically means another producer with the same transactional.id has been started: producerId: 0. epoch: 0. (org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.TransactionManager:505)
```

Need to look into the test itself with this PR merged.
